Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Integrated Dynamic Spectrum Access for Throughput, Delay, and Fairness Enhancement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central theme of this project is to investigate methodologies and theories to enhance throughput, delay, and fairness of cognitive radio networks via integrated dynamic spectrum access. The research will develop new methods to:
1) Extend spectrum sensing beyond just the presence and absence of the primary spectrum users' activities at certain spectrum bands/channels, but also their locations and transmit powers
2) Predict the primary spectrum user's activity and its interval using game theoretic and statistical learning approaches
3) Perform delay-aware spectrum management with a very comprehensive delay model considering all the factors that may affect the delivery latency of a packet, including the spectrum sensing delay, the transmission delay, the queuing delay, and the spectrum negotiation and scheduling delay
4) Share spectrum in a fair manner considering the tradeoff between fairness and throughput
5) Propose a delay-aware fair routing protocol for throughput optimization which jointly considers throughput, delay, and fairness along with dynamic spectrum management.

The project's focus on dynamic spectrum access is of high national interest and can create significant impact on spectral usage policies and related industries in the telecommunication and information technology sectors. The project will also encourage and include under-represented and minority students to be part of this activity, while extending education and outreach plans to undergraduates and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project description: With the dramatic increase of the spectrum demands, traditional spectrum assignment policies and methods of spectrum resources have led to the problem of spectrum scarcity. In contrast, a large portion of the licensed spectrum is still not in use or is considerably underutilized, resulting in an inefficient spectrum utilization. These unused/underutilized spectrum bands of the licensed spectrum, often referred to as spectrum holes or white spaces, can be exploited to increase spectrum utilization, thereby alleviating the spectrum scarcity problem. This has led to the emergence of the concept of Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA), a spectrum sharing paradigm with which unlicensed or secondary users (SUs) dynamically search for white spaces, and temporarily access them for wireless communications. To avoid causing interference to licensed or primary users (PUs), SUs have to continuously monitor the spectrum bands and yield to PUs whenever a PU starts using a spectrum band. DSA is made possible by the recent advances in cognitive radio (CR) technology, which can sense the surrounding spectrum environment through programming the digital processing engine, and accordingly adapt the radio parameters such as center frequency, bandwidth, transmit power, waveform, etc. This project addresses many of the fundamental problems and challenges of DSA to enable cognitive radio wireless networking (CRN). With the fast growth of the number of heterogeneous mobile devices and the advances of the rapid CR development, an environment that is full of communication devices with cognitive capabilities is foreseeable. In such a scenario how can we improve the performance of CRNs via a more effective and efficient exploitation of DSA? The central theme of this project is to investigate and develop novel methodologies and theories to enhance CRN performances (e.g., throughput, delay, and fairness) via integrated dynamic spectrum access.

Intellectual merit outcomes: The outcomes of this project are integrated techniques, protocols and mechanisms developed throughout the course of the project to enable dynamic and opportunistic use of and access to the available radio spectrum resources. Our developed techniques address various challenges pertaining to DSA, including mitigating jamming signals originated from malicious users, ensuring fair access to bandwidth among different spectrum users, ensuring location privacy of SUs while acquiring spectrum availability information, and overcomming high sampling rates required for wideband spectrum sensing and spectrum occupancy information recovery. The research findings obtained throughout this project have led to more than 35 publications, including more than 15 IEEE transactions/magazine papers, one Best Paper Award, and one U.S. patent.

Broader impact outcomes: At the research level, the broader impacts outcomes are technical solutions and mechanisms aimed at addressing the radio spectrum shortage problem, one of the major challenges that future wireless systems are facing. Our developed techniques serve as guidelines and backbone for promoting and establishing more flexible spectrum access policies and regulations. At the societal level, the obtained techniques aim to enable the general public with high-speed and concurrent access to public information, such as library, hospitals, and schools. Our research ?ndings have been disseminated through high-quality publications as well as presentations in focused workshops and conferences and are made accessible to the public. At the education level, the project involved students from under-represented groups, allowing them to obtained graduate (MS and PhD) degrees in engineering and giving them the opportunity to attend and participate in conferences. It also created the opportunity for minority students to participate and be involved in undergraduate research.
